content: The report provides an overview of FY2017 judiciary appropriations, detailing major actions such as budget submissions, hearings, markups, and the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017. The Budget for Fiscal Year 2017 requested $7.58 billion in new budget. The Budget for Fiscal Year 2017 requested $7.58 billion in new budget authority for judicial branch activities, including discretionary and mandatory funding for judges' salaries and benefits. The House and Senate Appropriations Subcommittees did not hold hearings on the FY2017 judicial branch budget request, but the House subcommittee accepted submissions from Members. On May 25, the House Appropriations Committee Subcommittee held a markup of the FY2017 Financial Services budget. The House subcommittee accepted programmatic and language submissions for the FY2017 budget request until March 17, 2016. On May 25, the House Appropriations Committee Subcommittee recommended $7.55 billion in funds for the judiciary, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits. On June 9, the House Appropriations Committee also recommended $7.55 billion in funds for the judiciary. The bill was ordered reported by a vote of 30-18. No amendments related to the judiciary were offered. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $7.58 billion in funds for the judiciary, including mandatory funds for judges' salaries and benefits under current law. The bill was ordered reported by a vote of 30-0. No amendments related to the judiciary were offered. The House agreed to a structured rule for consideration of the Financial Services and General Government bill. An amendment related to the judiciary was made in order, reducing funding by $1 million. The amended bill was passed with a vote of 239-185. No further action was taken on the bill before the start of FY2017. The judiciary funding for FY2017 was agreed upon with a vote of 239-185. Judicial branch activities were funded through various appropriations resolutions until the enactment of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2017. The act provided $7.5 billion for the judiciary, an increase of $176.2 million from FY2016. The judiciary funding for FY2015 was $7.344 billion, a 1.0% increase from FY2015. The funding was $184.1 million less than requested. In FY2014, funding was $7.261 billion, a 3.2% increase from FY2014, and $37.9 million less than requested. A funding gap in FY2014 led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days, which was resolved by a continuing resolution. The fiscal year began on October 1, 2013, with a funding gap leading to a government shutdown for 16 days. The gap was ended by a CR on October 17, 2013, providing funding until January 15, 2014. A consolidated appropriations bill on January 17, 2014, allocated $7.039 billion for the judiciary, comprising 0.2% of the total budget authority. The Supreme Court accounts for approximately 1% of the judiciary budget, with the rest funding lower federal courts and related services. The judiciary's budget, totaling approximately 1% of the total budget authority, covers the care of buildings and grounds by the Architect of the Capitol. The largest account, accounting for 72% of the budget, is for salaries and expenses of the U.S. Courts of Appeals, District Courts, and Other Judicial Services. Other significant accounts include Defender Services (13.9%) and Court Security (7.5%). The judiciary budget covers various expenses including salaries, Defender Services, Court Security, and other specialized courts not funded under the judiciary budget. The judiciary has achieved a cost reduction of nearly $1.5 billion over the past 10 years, focusing on shared administrative services and reducing space footprint. Efforts to improve judicial security have been spurred by various incidents, leading to increased safety measures. Efforts to enhance judicial security have been prompted by several violent incidents, including the double homicide of a federal judge's family members in Chicago in 2005, Atlanta courthouse killings in 2005, a state judge being shot in his Reno office in 2006, and a shooting at the Lloyd D. George U.S. Courthouse in Las Vegas in 2010. Measures such as intrusion detection systems for judges' homes and the Court Security Improvement Act of 2007 have been implemented to improve security for judges, court personnel, and the public. Collaboration with the U.S. Marshals Service has been crucial in ensuring adequate protective policies and practices are in place. The judiciary collaborates with the U.S. Marshals Service to enhance courtroom safety for the public. A pilot program was initiated in FY2009 for USMS to take over perimeter security at selected courthouses previously managed by FPS. USMS assumed primary security responsibility at seven courthouses in various locations. The program is being evaluated for improvements, with the judiciary reimbursing USMS for protective services. The judiciary collaborates with the U.S. Marshals Service to enhance courtroom safety at seven courthouses in different cities.
